required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 09, 2023
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Understanding the 'Wearing Off' Effect From Disease-modifying Therapies (DMT) in Patients With Multiple Sclerosis: an Interview Based Study Among Patients and Clinicians

brief_summary.textblock: This is a non-interventional, cross-sectional, qualitative study in which patients diagnosed with MS and clinicians with experience treating MS will be interviewed regarding patient experiences with the wearing off effect from ocrelizumab, natalizumab, and ofatumumab

primary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with key symptoms associated with the wearing off effect
primary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed at the time of interview with lookback period from time of first MS diagnosis, up to 3 months
primary_outcome.description: Number of participants with the following recurring symptoms will be collected: Fatigue Physical Pain Mobility issues or walking difficulties Numbness or sensory issues Cognitive difficulties Weakness Spasms Balance disturbance or dizziness Blurry vision or visual impairment Others

secondary_outcome.measure: Severity of wearing off effect symptoms
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed at the time of interview with lookback period from time of first MS diagnosis, up to 3 months

secondary_outcome.measure: Detailed language used to describe the experience of wearing off effect
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed at the time of interview with lookback period from time of first MS diagnosis, up to 3 months
secondary_outcome.description: Terms used to describe times when patients MS "gets better" and when it "gets worse" will be collected.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants switching from one therapy to another due to wearing off effect
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed at the time of interview with lookback period from time of first MS diagnosis, up to 3 months
secondary_outcome.description: Number of participants switching from one therapy to another due to wearing off effect will be collected

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants who changed the dosing/infusion schedules due to wearing off effect
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed at the time of interview with lookback period from time of first MS diagnosis, up to 3 months
secondary_outcome.description: Number of participants who changed the dosing/infusion schedules due to wearing off effect will be collected

secondary_outcome.measure: Dissimilarities of clinician' and patients' views of wearing off effect
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed at the time of interview with lookback period from time of first MS diagnosis, up to 3 months
secondary_outcome.description: Assessed qualitatively via concept coding techniques

intervention.description: Non-interventional, cross-sectional, qualitative study. There is no treatment allocation. Patients prescribed with Disease-modifying therapy in the commercial setting are eligible to enroll into this study.

Non-interventional, cross-sectional, qualitative study. There is no treatment allocation. Patients prescribed with Disease-modifying therapy in the commercial setting are eligible to enroll into this study.

Non-interventional, cross-sectional, qualitative study. There is no treatment allocation. Patients prescribed with Disease-modifying therapy in the commercial setting are eligible to enroll into this study.

study_pop.textblock: Adult patients diagnosed with MS and clinicians with experience treating MS from Germany, UK, and US
